question: The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law.
tip: The Magna Carta established the idea that even the king was subject to the law.

question: When is Mother's Day?
Dylan Thomas was a famous writer and poet from which country?
tip: Dylan Thomas, who lived from 1914 until 1953, was a Welsh poet and writer. One of his famous works is Under Milk Wood.

question: What term arose after the evacuation of 300,000 people from the beaches?
tip: Many civilian volunteers in small pleasure and fishing boats from Britain helped the Navy to rescue more than 300,000 men from the beaches around Dunkirk. The evacuation gave rise to the phrase ‘the Dunkirk spirit’.

What tools did the Bronze age people introduce?
tip: The people of the Bronze Age were accomplished metalworkers who made many beautiful objects in bronze and gold, including tools, ornaments and weapons.

question: Blind people can get a 50% discount on their TV licence
tip: Blind people can get a 50% discount on their TV licence

question: Where is the Tate art gallery located?
tip: Works by British and international artists are displayed in galleries across the UK. Some of the most well-known galleries are The National Gallery, Tate Britain and Tate Modern in London, the National Museum in Cardiff, and the National Gallery of Scotland in Edinburgh.

question: Everyone celebrates New Year on the First January in Britain
options: No it's celebrated on the 1st December
No it celebrated on the 25th December

question: How often are the General Elections held?
tip: MPs are elected at a General Election, which is held at least every five years.

question: The Wimbledon Championships are associated with motor sports.
tip: The Wimbledon Championships are associated with tennis.

question: Which TWO buildings were built during the Middle Ages?
tip: The Middle Ages also saw a change in the type of buildings in Britain. Castles were built in many places in Britain and Ireland, partly for defence. Today many are in ruins, although some, such as Windsor and Edinburgh, are still in use. Great cathedrals – for example, Lincoln Cathedral – were also built, and many of these are still used for worship.

question: Where can Crown Jewels be seen?
tip: Crown Jewels can be seen in the Tower of London.

question: British scientists were the first to clone a mammal successfully and the animal was a rabbit
tip: The British team used a sheep for the first mammal cloning and the sheep was called Dolly

Which TWO British Actors have recently won Oscars?
tip: British actors continue to be popular and continue to win awards throughout the world. Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

question: What is the distance (in miles) between the North coast of Scotland and the South coast of England?

Which of the following are two famous British inventors of the 20th century?
options: Tim Berners Lee and Isambard Kingdom Brunel
Isambard Kingdom Brunel and John Logie Baird
Alan Turing and Isambard Kingdom Brunel
Tim Berners Lee and Alan Turing
tip: A Turing machine is a theoretical mathematical device invented by Alan Turing (1912–54), a British mathematician, in the 1930s. The inventor of the World Wide Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee is British.

question: All acts of Parliaments made in who's name?
tip: The Queen has important ceremonial roles, such as the opening of the new parliamentary session each year. On this occasion the Queen makes a speech which summarises the government's policies for the year ahead. All Acts of Parliament are made in her name.

question: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC but this was unsuccessful. For how many years did Britain remain separate from the Roman Empire?
tip: Julius Caesar led a Roman invasion of Britain in 55 BC. This was unsuccessful and for nearly 100 years Britain remained separate from the Roman Empire. In AD 43 the Emperor Claudius led the Roman army in a new invasion. This time, there was resistance from some of the British tribes but the Romans were successful in occupying almost all of Britain.

tip: William Blake, Lord Byron and Robert Browning were all 19th-century poets.

Which TWO fought in wars against Napoleon?
tip: Admiral Lord Nelson commanded the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar in 1805. He died during the battle. The Duke of Wellington defeated Napoleon at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815.

question: The House of Lords always acts as the government wishes.
tip: The House of Lords is normally more independent of government than the House of Commons.

question: Where do Beefeaters serve as tour guides?
In 1783, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments.
tip: In 1776, 13 American colonies declared their independence, stating that people had a right to establish their own governments. The colonists eventually defeated the British army and Britain recognised the colonies’ independence in 1783.

options: The MP in charge of Health
The leader of the opposition party
The leader of the party in power

options: No, it is only for state retirement pension

question: Which Two British film actors have recently won Oscars?
tip: Recent British actors to have won Oscars include Colin Firth, Sir Anthony Hopkins, Dame Judi Dench, Kate Winslet and Tilda Swinton.

question: What is known as 'canvassing'?
options: Persuade people to vote for the party you represent
Filling in the ballot paper for those who cannot do it themselves
tip: Political parties are particularly busy at election times. Members work hard to persuade people to vote for their candidates - for instance, by handing out leaflets in the street or by knocking on people's doors and asking for their support.

Which TWO are British overseas territories?
tip: There are several British overseas territories in other parts of the world, such as the Falkland Islands and St Helena. They are linked to the UK but not part of it.

question: Bank Holidays are at the beginning of May, in late May or early June, and in August
Robert Stephenson and George were famous pioneers of which industry?
tip: Just before Victoria came to the throne, the father and son George and Robert Stephenson pioneered the railway engine and a major expansion of the railways took place in the Victorian period. Railways were built throughout the Empire.

question: For which TWO subjects are the Secretaries of State responsible?
tip: Secretaries of State are responsible for subjects such as education, health and defence.

question: Which TWO of the following are protected by law from discrimination?
tip: There are laws to ensure that people are not treated unfairly in any area of work or life because of their disability, marital status, age, pregnancy and maternity, race, religion or belief, or sexuality.
